instruction: What does Bing need to do to beat Google?
output:
Terry Myerson, Microsoft's executive vice president of the Windows and Devices Group, just about summed up the company's strategy for the next version of its smartphone OS during an event in San Francisco on Wednesday.
In many ways, it's a continuation of the existing Microsoft strategy for mobile -- one that emphasizes enterprise appeal above all else -- but there are a few notable changes as well. The update, known as Windows 10 Mobile, will be available for free to existing Windows Phone 8.1 handsets this fall, and it will also run on new devices from partners like Alcatel, HP, and Lenovo.
Microsoft is joining the likes of BlackBerry and Palm by embracing the concept of a single OS shared across multiple device types. In this case, the end goal is to bring together Windows 10 apps onto phones, tablets, and even PCs. While you won't find touch-friendly versions of full desktop apps on your phone anytime soon, Microsoft has already announced that Office Mobile apps like Word, Excel, and PowerPoint will be universal across all Windows 10 devices.
Just as importantly, the OS will support Continuum, which lets you connect your phone to a mouse and keyboard and use it as a desktop computer. It will also support universal tasks like taking a phone call on your PC or resuming a video on your TV that you started on your phone.
And yes, Microsoft did confirm that Windows 10 Mobile will run on ARM chips, too, though it didn't offer any specific hardware partners yet.
Windows 10 Mobile will support all the same key enterprise features as the PC and tablet editions of Windows 10, including support for enterprise mobile management (EMM) tools (including tools like Samsung's Knox), secure boot,

instruction: Why do men earn more on average?
output:
Gender pay gap remains stubbornly persistent.
Another month, another report showing that the UK gender pay gap has barely shifted. The Equality and Human Rights Commission’s latest statistics reveal that women are still paid 18.1% less than men on average (down from 18.4% in 2016). This is bad news for the government, which had hoped to close the gap by 2025. It is also bad news for anyone who believes that progress is being made towards a fairer society.
There is plenty of speculation as to why this gap persists. Some argue that it is due to discrimination and bias in hiring and promotion practices. Others blame it on occupational segregation and different choices between men and women about work-life balance. But these factors cannot explain the entirety of the gap.
When we look at the difference in hourly pay between full-time workers, there is no gender pay gap among those aged 16-29. Why? Because when young people enter the labour market they are allocated to jobs with lower earning potential, regardless of their gender. For example, they are more likely to be employed in the retail and hospitality industries, where wages are low. As a result, when we compare all workers regardless of age, the gender pay gap increases to 18.1%.
In fact, the gender pay gap starts to emerge in the first year of a person’s working life. By the time they are 29, those who started work as babies doing unpaid family work receive lower wages than others, so the gap widens again. This can be explained by the “gender socialisation” of new entrants into the labour market. Young women are socialised to prioritise caring over paid employment, while young men are social

instruction: What language family does Hungarian belong to?
output:
Welcome to the Hungarian language page! Here you will find information about the Hungarian language, where it is spoken and some common phrases.
Hungarian belongs to the Ugric group of languages that are part of the Finno-Ugric family of languages, which also includes Estonian and Finnish. These languages are unrelated to any other language families in Europe. Hungarian is spoken by approximately 14 million people, mostly in Hungary, but also in parts of Romania, Slovakia, Serbia, Ukraine, and Austria. It is an agglutinative language, meaning that words are formed by adding suffixes and prefixes to roots or stems. Hungarian has a complex system of vowel harmony, which is one of its distinguishing features.

your plant is suffering from too much moisture. The leaves are quite thin and they cannot hold a lot of water. When the soil is too wet, the leaves start to rot and eventually fall off. Instead, water the plant at the soil level to avoid rotting the thin leaves of your snake plant.

instruction: How do I make poached eggs at home?
output:
If you’ve never made a poached egg at home before, it might seem like a complicated process. But, in reality, it is one of the easiest things to cook because all you need are a few ingredients and a pot of boiling water.
1. Crack eggs into a small bowl and add about 1 to 2 tablespoons of cold water. Beat the eggs with a fork until they have a uniform, smooth consistency. To make an omlette you can beat in some milk and seasoning, which makes them even tastier.
You can also use a whisk to break up the eggs if you don’t have a fork.
2. Put a saucepan over medium-high heat and fill it with water so that it reaches about 3 inches (8 cm) deep. You should be able to place at least one finger between the surface of the water and the bottom of the pan without touching the bottom of the pan.
Make sure that the water doesn’t reach too high. Place a lid on the pan. This will stop a lot of steam from getting out, which means that your eggs won’t end up being overcooked.
3. Gently slide your eggs into the pan once the water is hot. Cook for about 6 minutes. Use a slotted spoon to take the eggs out of the pan when they are done.
4. Serve with your preferred side dishes. Enjoy!
wikiHow to Make Poached Eggs

instruction: I live in the Bay Area and I've had it with PG&E. Devise a plan to start a competing energy company to put them out of business.
output:
So far nobody has come up with a compelling plan to start a competing energy company.  Every attempt I've seen so far has assumed that the government will allow them to somehow do this without competition from PG&E.  I don't see how that can happen.
At the very least, you need to get past all the regulatory barriers erected by PG&E.  If you could crack those, then you would be in business.  The most efficient way to do this is to buy out a local co-op and threaten to shut down service unless they are allowed to join your new co-op.
Here are some of the major regulatory barriers:
1. You can't just build a power line and connect it to the grid.  PG&E controls where the lines go and who pays for what.  It costs about $20M/mile to string a new line.  They have thousands of miles of line.  
2. You can't just start buying power from somewhere else.  PG&E gets preferential treatment on their purchases because they control the switches as well.  They also get a penalty if they don't use all the power they generate.  This means they have an economic incentive to generate more than they need.  If you start buying from somewhere else, they can sue you for damages and they can also cut you off.  This is why Apple's "renewable" program with PG&E doesn't work.  Apple signed a contract with PG&E to only buy renewable power.  When the sun isn't shining or the wind isn't blowing, Apple takes power from the rest of the grid.  PG&E generates extra power at these times and charges Apple less for it.  Apple pays about half of what the rest of

instruction: I'm looking for a game to play with a large group of friends.
output:
Between 5 and 10 players.
I've never played it but I've been told that it's really fun.
It is pretty fun, we called it "drunkie" back in college when we played it, I think the original name is "Amnesia".
Basically everyone picks a number between 1-100 and those are the points you're aiming for. You take turns drawing cards from a deck of 104 (4x27) and try to get as close to your number as possible with the card values adding up to your number. So if you have 79 points and draw an Ace of Spades which is worth 11, you can either keep it or discard it since your score is now 88 (Ace is wild).
The cool part is there are 3 different decks, and you can play multiple rounds with the same group adding up your scores at the end of each round. It is pretty easy to teach, and once you start playing, it flies by.

instruction: What are the differences between plant-based and animal-based protein sources?

instruction: What are some potential implications of using a single-use plastic bottle versus a reusable bottle on both the environment and human health?
output:
The potential implications of using a single-use plastic bottle versus a reusable bottle on both the environment and human health are significant.
Firstly, single-use plastic bottles are often made from polyethylene terephthalate (PET) which is a type of plastic that takes hundreds of years to decompose. When these bottles end up in landfills, they release toxic chemicals such as dioxins and furans that can contaminate soil and groundwater. In addition, when plastic bottles are incinerated, they emit harmful pollutants such as dioxins and furans into the air.
Secondly, single-use plastic bottles have a significant impact on the environment due to their production process. The manufacturing of plastic bottles requires large amounts of energy and resources, as well as the use of hazardous chemicals such as chlorine and benzene. This process also generates significant amounts of greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change.
On the other hand, reusable bottles are made from materials such as stainless steel, glass, or silicone, which are non-toxic and do not contribute to environmental pollution. Reusable bottles also reduce waste by avoiding the need for single-use plastic bottles. Additionally, reusable bottles can be washed and sanitized, reducing the risk of bacterial contamination.
From a human health perspective, single-use plastic bottles can leach harmful chemicals such as phthalates and bisphenol A (BPA) into the water they contain. These chemicals have been linked to various health problems such as reproductive issues, obesity, and cancer.
In conclusion, the choice between single-use plastic bottles and reusable bottles has significant implications

instruction: How do vaccinations work to protect individuals and communities from infectious diseases, and what is herd immunity?
output:
How do vaccinations work to protect individuals and communities from infectious diseases, and what is herd immunity?
Vaccinations expose the immune system to a small amount of a disease so that it learns how to fight it. This prevents people from getting the actual disease in the future. Herd immunity occurs when a large percentage of the population is vaccinated, which protects those who cannot be vaccinated, such as babies or those with weakened immune systems.

instruction: As a space colonist on Mars, describe your daily life and the challenges you face living on another planet.
output:
What would your day be like?
I wake up to the sound of my alarm clock, which is set to Martian time. I get out of bed and get dressed in my space suit. Then I head down to the breakfast buffet, where I have a delicious Mars-grown omelet with some Martian coffee. After breakfast, I head to work. I am an engineer at the Mars colony, so I spend my day working on various projects related to colonizing Mars. One day I might be working on building a new greenhouse to grow more food, while another day I might be testing out a new type of fuel cell that can be used to generate power for the colony.
Life on Mars can be challenging, but it's also very rewarding. The weather can be unpredictable and harsh, with severe dust storms that can last for days. The air is thin and requires special equipment to breathe. And of course, there's the constant threat of asteroids and other space debris that can damage our facilities or even endanger our lives. But despite these challenges, we are determined to make Mars a livable planet for future generations.

instruction: Write a script for a YouTube video exploring the history and cultural significance of jazz.
output:
Jazz is a music genre that originated in the African American communities of New Orleans, Louisiana, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It was a fusion of African and European music traditions, including blues, ragtime, and brass band music. Jazz quickly became popular throughout the United States, and by the 1920s it had spread to Europe.
The history of jazz is closely tied to the history of African Americans in the United States. It was a way for black people to express their culture and identity in the face of oppression and discrimination. Jazz musicians often faced challenges due to racism and segregation, but they also found ways to innovate and thrive.
Jazz has had a profound impact on American culture. It has been used as a vehicle for social commentary, political protest, and cultural expression. It has also been embraced by audiences around the world, and has become an important part of the global music scene.
Today, jazz continues to evolve and adapt, with new artists pushing the boundaries of the genre. It remains an important part of American culture, and continues to inspire and influence other musical genres.

Hebrew (עִבְרִית, pronounced [ivrit]) is a Semitic language of the Afro-Asiatic language family. Historically, it developed from the ancient Canaanite language which was spoken in the Levant region of the eastern Mediterranean coast of the former United States of Israel and the Kingdom of Judah. The earliest written evidence of Hebrew is a blessing from the 10th century BCE. The Hebrew alphabet, the second most used writing system in the world today, was originally a consonantal alphabet composed of 22 letters. It is written right to left, like Arabic; unlike Arabic, vowels are not usually indicated by separate letters but rather are understood from their context within the word, or sometimes by using matres lectionis. Modern Hebrew is one of the official languages of Israel, while Classical Hebrew is studied in Jewish religious establishments and has been the literary standard of Judaism for over two thousand years.

instruction: Does P=NP?
output:
The following text is the first part of an article by Scott Aaronson in SICOMP 2013, which was published in the ACM Computing Reviews:


P=BPP ?

There's a popular joke among computer scientists that if you ask three of them a question, you'll get four different answers. This jocular observation can sometimes be taken too far. A prominent physicist told me recently that he thought quantum computers would never work because “nobody understands quantum mechanics,” and yet somehow we build quantum devices and control their behavior with near-perfect fidelity. (He was unimpressed when I tried to explain about measurements and decoherence.) So maybe it shouldn't come as a surprise that there are some computer scientists who don't believe P=NP, despite the overwhelming preponderance of evidence; after all, nobody really understands quantum mechanics either. And perhaps I'm uniquely susceptible to this kind of psychological manipulation, but the more I read David Cherry's new paper, “The P = BPP? Hypothesis,” the less I'm convinced that his arguments constitute a serious challenge to the standard model of computation.
The basic idea behind Cherry's paper is that P != NP unless one adds extra structure to the class of problems solvable in polynomial time. Not only does this structure have to make a difference when it comes to hard instances of NP-complete problems, but it has to do so in a way that gives rise to a subexponential-size circuit for most Boolean functions. There's already a lot of interesting physics here—for instance, we want a subclass of NP whose problems are easy to simulate on a quantum Turing machine, but we also don't want it to be too small!—

output:
I haven't done the actual math, but I would say that renting is almost certainly the better financial choice.
The main reason is that you are only going to be there for 5 years, and after that time frame, you can move someplace else. When you own your own place, you are stuck with it until you sell it which could take months or years. If you rent, you can just pack up your bags and leave.
Also, keep in mind that if you own a place, you have to pay property taxes on it. Those can add up to hundreds or even thousands of dollars per year.
Finally, when you buy, you need to factor in closing costs and realtor fees. If you rent, then you don't need to worry about any of that.

instruction: Write a short story based on the following prompt:  “Ninja visibility peaked in the 1980’s, and as you can see it’s been on a steady decline since. The consensus of most ninjologists is that they’re extinct, but I disagree. I think they’ve perfected their technique. And I think I can prove it.”
output:
The year was 2087 and the world had changed drastically. Once mighty empires had fallen, while new nations rose from the ashes of old. The ninja clans had long since vanished from public view, their methods and secrets lost to history. But some said they were not gone forever, that they had merely adapted and evolved beyond the sight of mortal men.
Agent Smith worked for an organization dedicated to the study of the ninja, or “ninjologists” as they called themselves. He had been on a mission to Japan to investigate a possible sighting of a living ninja when his team received word of a breakthrough in their research.
“The consensus of most ninjologists is that they’re extinct,” his boss had told him over the comms unit, “but I disagree. I think they’ve perfected their technique. And I think I can prove it.”
Smith boarded a shuttle for Narita Airport, the site of what would surely be a historic discovery. As he walked down the jetway, he could feel the weight of the world on his shoulders. If he was right about this, it could mean a major breakthrough for his discipline, but if he was wrong… well, he didn’t like to think about that possibility.
As he entered the terminal, he felt a presence behind him. Without turning around, he knew it was her.
“I see you have brought the outsider,” a voice whispered in his ear.
Smith turned with a smile and bowed respectfully before his teacher, Master Kimoto.
“You must be careful, Agent Smith. The world is not what it once was. There are those who would seek to use our art for evil purposes. We must be vigilant if we are to preserve it for future generations.”
Smith nodded in understanding.

The question is, what do investigators do with all those photos once the case is closed? “They're archived,” said Unit Chief Michael Murphy, Homicide Branch, Special Investigations Bureau of the LAPD. “The photographs are stored for about seven years, and then they're destroyed.” Murphy said that in some cases, detectives will ask the DA's office to keep the photos on file so they can be used as evidence in future criminal prosecutions. He added that detectives themselves can request copies of crime scene photos to maintain a personal record of a case.

instruction: Why do most plastics turn white when you bend them?
output:
Ever wondered why plastic bends white?
When you bend a plastic, it is stretched. The molecules in the plastic are held together by weak forces called van der Waals forces. When you stretch them, these forces become weaker and the molecules move apart. This causes the plastic to turn white. The same thing happens when you pull a rubber band – it turns white because the van der Waals forces become weaker.

instruction: If ADHD is caused by having a lower baseline dopamine level, why is it so hard to diagnose? Can't we just measure dopamine levels?
output:
Dopamine levels do not fluctuate as much as serotonin (5-HT) levels. The amount of dopamine in the synaptic cleft changes only with the amount of dopamine released from the presynaptic nerve terminal, which depends on how many dopamine receptors are activated by the neurotransmitter.
The actual release of dopamine is less than 1% of the total amount that was stored in vesicles in the presynaptic terminal. Therefore, measuring brain dopamine levels would require the injection of extremely large amounts of dopamine into the brain to measure any change in brain levels. Also, dopamine is widely distributed in the brain and has multiple functions which vary depending on its location. For example, high levels of dopamine in the prefrontal cortex have been associated with reduced impulsivity, while high levels in the striatum are associated with reduced motor activity.

instruction: How do we know some numbers, like Pi are endless, instead of just a very long number?
output:
How do we know some numbers, like Pi are endless, instead of just a very long number?
Dear Editor, You have given me an excellent opportunity to bring out one of the most fascinating aspects of mathematics: It is not just about numbers and formulas. It is also about beautiful ideas that have deep meanings. One such idea is that of infinity. Infinity is a concept that has intrigued humans since ancient times. The idea of “something that goes on forever” is beautiful in its simplicity. And when mathematicians started to explore this idea further, they found that there were many different kinds of infinity. There is “countably infinite”, which means that you can put a one-to-one correspondence between the numbers and the objects (like the integers and the points of a line). Then there is “uncountably infinite”, which is bigger than countably infinite. For example, the real numbers are uncountably infinite — you cannot put them into one-to-one correspondence with the counting numbers. But there are even more kinds of infinity. For example, how big is infinity? This is a famous question that has been debated by philosophers for centuries. Some say that infinity is larger than anything else. Others say that it cannot be compared to anything else because it is completely different. One particularly beautiful kind of infinity is transfinite infinity. This is a bit tricky to explain, but I will give it a try. Imagine that you have a set of all the natural numbers (1, 2, 3, …). Now we can create a new set by adding a new element called “aleph-null”. So far so good. But then we can create a new set by adding “aleph-null” — aleph-null is used to denote any object that is one-to-one...

instruction: In the US, onions are the only commodity that can not be traded as a futures contract due to 1958 Onion Futures Act. Why was this restriction not repealed along with other deregulation measures of 80s and 90s? Why was onion seen as different from other commodities?
output:
commodities agriculture futures
Sounds like you've already figured out the answer. The Onion Futures Act was signed into law by President Gerald Ford in 1958, and it has never been repealed despite numerous other commodity futures laws being struck down or repealed since then.
The reasons why onions have special treatment is that:
Onions are a "perishable" item, and are easily spoiled or wasted before they can be delivered to market.
Onions are not widely consumed in the United States, so there is little price risk protection for farmers or hedging for buyers.
Therefore, there is insufficient demand for onion futures trading.
Lack of demand for onion futures means smaller volume, and therefore lower fees for traders. This means fewer people will offer their services as a broker/trader for onion futures.
Overall, this lack of interest in trading onion futures makes it less likely that onion futures contracts will ever be profitable enough to attract legislation to repeal the act.

Do you know where you read it? Do you remember who said it? instruction: Why is the musical scale the way it is: 12 keys: 7 major, 5 minor?
output:
With each diatonic scale one can construct 7 major and 5 minor triads.
The reason is that there are 12 notes in an octave, and each note has three possible pitches (or overtones), so there are 36 notes in an octave. Starting with C, the first note of the C scale, there are three ways to play C: C, C# (D♭), and C♮ (D). Continuing up the scale, each note has three more possibilities, giving us:

C, D, E, F, G, A, B, C♯, D♭, E♭, F♭, G♭, A♭, B♭, C
Then going back down, we get:

C, B♭, A♭, G♭, F♭, E♭, D♭, C♯, B, A, G, F, E, D, C
And going back up again:

C, B, A, G, F, E, D, C♯, B♯, A♯, G♯, F♯, E♯, D♯, C
So there are 12 different notes when starting on C, and any time you transpose a note by a semitone, you have another note. This gives us 36 different notes per octave.
If we start on any other note, say A, then the first three notes are:
A, B, C, D, E, F, G, A♯, B♯, C♯, D♯, E♯, F♯, G♯, A
Transposing up and down from A gives us all the other keys as well.
This means that if we were to play a major or minor chord with every note in the octave, it would take 36 x 36 = 12

instruction: Are there any academic fields that don't have enough people trying to teach?
output:
Sociology and Anthropology are two such fields.
The majority of the college students I know who are studying these disciplines are doing so because they have no clear career goals, and their parents told them that they should study something "easy" (since both of these subjects are relatively easy to understand, while not requiring much actual skill or practice to do them well).
More people should be studying these subjects, but they don't really have practical use outside of academia. But we could make them more practical by teaching people skills like how to apply for jobs and write resumes.
I don't think it is a problem of too few interested students. Rather it is a problem of too few professors willing to teach these subjects. There aren't many places in the world where you can get a job with a degree in sociology or anthropology unless you also majored in something else. And even if you managed to find a job in your field, it wouldn't be very prestigious. So why would anyone want to become a professor in either of those fields?
Anthropology isn't exactly lacking in practitioners... it's just that most anthropologists are working as consultants for various government agencies or large corporations rather than on university faculties. The Bureau of Labor Statistics classifies anthropologists as "social scientists," and estimates that there were 23,500 of them employed in the US in 2014. Most of them are employed as follows:
Archaeologists	--	6,800
Market research analysts --	3,700
Social scientists, all other	--	3,600
Public relations specialists	--	3,300
Historians	--	3,300
Sociologists	--

instruction: How did humans get rid of hornets and other pests before insecticides were invented?
output:
Humans have been fighting hornets for centuries, and they had to get rid of them the hard way. The only insecticides we had back then were made from crushed insects, which is pretty disgusting. Today we have DDT and other chemical insecticides that are safe for people and pets, but in the old days we didn’t. People used things like vinegar, boric acid, and even garlic to kill these pests.
Vinegar is a popular choice because it kills most insects on contact. It also leaves behind a smell that repels future invaders. Mix one part white vinegar with four parts water and spray it around your home to keep the hornets away. You can also make a spray by combining equal parts apple cider vinegar and water. This will work just as well.
Boric acid is another effective way to get rid of hornets. This stuff is toxic to insects, so you don’t have to worry about hurting yourself or your family. Mix 1/4 cup of boric acid with 1/4 cup of sugar and put it into a jar. Put the lid on tightly so the ants can’t get out. Place the jar where you see the hornets and they will carry the poison back to their nest. In a few days, you should see a big reduction in their numbers.
Garlic has natural insecticidal properties that can help get rid of hornets. Crush up a few cloves of garlic and sprinkle them around your house. You can also make a spray by mixing 20 drops of garlic oil with 2 cups of water. Spray this around your home to keep the hornets away.
Even though these methods might seem a little strange, they do work

instruction: I don’t even understand what it means to ask “what is the meaning of life?” What are people asking, and what kind of answer are they looking for?
output:
I think people are searching for answers to the big questions. Why are we here? What’s the purpose of life? What happens when we die? I’m not sure that there is one answer or even a “correct” answer, but I do think that people are looking for some sense of peace or comfort in knowing about the big stuff. The problem is that those questions can’t really be answered with facts or logic, they require a leap of faith or an emotional connection.
If you ask me what the meaning of life is, I will say that it depends on your perspective. Everyone has their own interpretation and beliefs, and ultimately the question is unanswerable.

instruction: I live in the Midwest of U.S., where we love using salt to de-ice our roads. This causes quite a bit of rusting on the underside of cars. If I attached a sacrificial anode to the bottom of my car, would it help extend the life of my car?
output:
corrosion prevention rust cars
$\begingroup$ Are you willing to modify the car in any way? Coat the underside with epoxy or something similar? $\endgroup$ – Jon Custer Mar 10 '17 at 16:42
$\begingroup$ @JonCuster No, I'm not willing to modify the car. I was thinking more along the lines of placing a sheet of aluminum underneath the car that would be attached to the anode. $\endgroup$ – user39588 Mar 10 '17 at 16:44
$\begingroup$ Aluminum would certainly be better than nothing... but it wouldn't be perfect. As others have mentioned, most of your corrosion will be where the road salt is directly touching the metal, and not where the salt is dripping down from above. For maximum benefit, you want to maximize the surface area of your sacrificial anode (and thus the amount of electrons it can give up). To do this without modifying the car, you could attach strips of aluminum to the bottom of the tires (or put some kind of skid-plate under them), and also coat/paint the inside of any wheel wells (where the road salt tends to collect) as well. $\endgroup$ – Ben Crowell Mar 11 '17 at 0:42
The idea is sound: the sacrificial anode will corrode instead of the car. However, there are two problems with your proposed method:

instruction: How close ethnically are modern Greeks to the ancient Greeks?
output:
Modern Greeks are as close to ancient Greeks as any modern European people are to ancient Europeans.
In ancient Greece, the Greeks had a wide variety of languages and dialects that differed from one another. Some are still spoken today in the form of Greek dialects, while others are extinct. For example, ancient Spartan was very different from the Attic Greek of Athens, which is considered the standard of classical Greek.
What language did they speak in ancient Greece?
The Ancient Greeks spoke a group of dialects known as "Greek" (also referred to as "Hellenic" or "Koine"). These dialects are the ancestors of the modern Greek language. The Greek used in literature and philosophy in the Classical period came to be known as "koinē diathḗkḗ", or "common speech", hence "Greek" in English. By the time of the Roman Empire, Greek was spoken over a large area, from Italy to northern India, and was the lingua franca of the civilized world, along with Latin. It remained an important language of religion, science and philosophy even after the decline of the Greco-Roman world.

instruction: How should I do time manage spreading time working on multiple projects? For example, should I "time block" your calendar and say 8am to 10am I work Project A. And 10am to 11am I work on Project B. What are other methods besides time blocking?
output:
For example, you could use the Pomodoro Technique. There are also other time management techniques that will help with multitasking and focusing on multiple tasks:
1. The Eisenhower Matrix divides tasks into four quadrants depending on their urgency and how important they are. Tasks in the upper right are things you should do immediately, those in the upper left are tasks you can do later, tasks in the lower right are tasks that can be delegated to others, and those in the lower left are tasks that aren't worth doing at all. Prioritize according to this matrix and tackle the upper right first.
2. One of the best ways to stop multitasking is to batch similar tasks together. For example, if you are working on several reports, create a playlist of songs or podcasts to listen to while you do all of them.
3. Learning to say "no" and setting boundaries around your time is an important skill for effective time management. If you feel overworked and overwhelmed, think about what you can stop doing so you have more time to focus on the tasks that really matter.
4. Instead of working on multiple projects at once, you could work on them one after the other. This might be necessary if you only have enough bandwidth to complete one task at a time.
